blocks.text: Our equation thus reduces to $du = 0$, or by integrating, to $u = C$, but  $u = [P(x) y + Q(y) x$ being constant], and hence we have the rule as given.

Here
$$
 rac{dy}{dx} =  rac{44y - 4y^2 - 2x^2}{4y - 4y^2 - 2x^2},
$$
and thus the equation is exact.

If $P(x,y)$ as (though $k$ were a constant)
$$
 rac{dy}{dx} = - rac{(44y - 4y^2 - 2x^2)}{(4y - 4y^2 - 2x^2)},
$$
but of this only the $k$ must be taken, since there can be always been attained by the integration of terms containing $x$.

If this equation is multiplied through by $v$, we have a form on the left-hand side with which we are familiar, viz.
$$
du =  rac{du}{dx} + v = C.
$$
[This equation might have been regarded as one made exact through multiplication by the integrating factor $v$.]
